abstract.p: New York Islanders and Tampa Bay Lightning skate to 3-3 tie (M)

block.p: If the Tampa Bay Lightning is any barometer, the Islanders are an improved team from last season. That's how Islanders Coach Butch Goring sees it. A year after losing to the Lightning in their regular-season opener, the Islanders tonight opened their season with a 3-3 tie before 20,686, a record for the Ice Palace.
''We're just a much more in-control hockey team,'' Goring said of his team featuring 12 new players. ''And we didn't make as many mistakes.''

If the Tampa Bay Lightning is any barometer, the Islanders are an improved team from last season. That's how Islanders Coach Butch Goring sees it. A year after losing to the Lightning in their regular-season opener, the Islanders tonight opened their season with a 3-3 tie before 20,686, a record for the Ice Palace.
''We're just a much more in-control hockey team,'' Goring said of his team featuring 12 new players. ''And we didn't make as many mistakes.''

The opener had some good and not-so-good aspects for the Islanders to mull before their next game at Toronto on Tuesday. They were 0 for 8 on power plays, yet also held the Lightning to 24 shots over 65 minutes.
''We had a lot of opportunities,'' Goring said of the power play. ''We were as good as we could be without scoring. We're going to find the net sooner or later.''

The Islanders, who couldn't capitalize on a power play in the last 1 minute 23 seconds of overtime, have still not won a regular-season opener since Jan. 21, 1995, of the lockout-shortened 1994-95 season.

It nevertheless was a distinguished night for Islanders center Claude Lapointe. He tied the score 9:57 into the third with his second eye-catching goal of the night. He stole the puck and came roaring up the ice, flanked by right wing Mark Parrish. At the last instant, he faked a pass and stuffed the puck by goalie Dan Cloutier.
''That was a Wayne Gretzky-type move,'' Goring said.
''In my dreams,'' Lapointe said when told of Goring's sentiment.
Islanders defenseman Roman Hamrlik staked them to an early lead when he decided suddenly to shoot from the left point and beat Cloutier on the glove side at 7:36 into the game.

The teams would go on to play a penalty-filled game, as Tampa Bay Coach Steve Ludzik had predicted considering the league's tighter enforcement of slashing. There were 20 penalties called, 10 on the Islanders.
